chapter.heading: MULTIMODAL FREIGHT TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND INFORMATION

section.heading: State freight advisory committees

subsection.heading: In General.—
subsection.chapeau: The Secretary of Transportation shall encourage each State to establish a freight advisory committee consisting of a representative cross-section of public and private sector freight stakeholders, including representatives of—

paragraph.content: ports, if applicable;
freight railroads, if applicable;
shippers;
carriers;
freight-related associations;
third-party logistics providers;
the freight industry workforce;
the transportation department of the State;
metropolitan planning organizations;
local governments;
the environmental protection department of the State, if applicable;
the air resources board of the State, if applicable;
economic development agencies of the State; and
not-for-profit organizations or community organizations.

subsection.heading: Qualifications.—
subsection.chapeau: Each member of a freight advisory committee established under subsection (a) shall have qualifications sufficient to serve on a freight advisory committee, including, as applicable—

paragraph.content: general business and financial experience;
experience or qualifications in the areas of freight transportation and logistics;
experience in transportation planning;
experience representing employees of the freight industry;
experience representing a State, local government, or metropolitan planning organization; or
experience representing the views of a community group or not-for-profit organization.

subsection.heading: Role of Committee.—
subsection.chapeau: A freight advisory committee of a State described in subsection (a) shall—

paragraph.content: advise the State on freight-related priorities, issues, projects, and funding needs;
serve as a forum for discussion for State transportation decisions affecting freight mobility;
communicate and coordinate regional priorities with other organizations;
promote the sharing of information between the private and public sectors on freight issues; and
participate in the development of the freight plan of the State described in section 70202, including by providing advice regarding the development of the freight investment plan.

section.heading: State freight plans

subsection.heading: In General.—
subsection.content: Each State that receives funding under section 167 of title 23 shall develop a freight plan that provides a comprehensive plan for the immediate and long-range planning activities and investments of the State with respect to freight.

subsection.heading: Plan Contents.—
subsection.chapeau: A State freight plan described in subsection (a) shall include, at a minimum—

paragraph.content: an identification of significant freight system trends, needs, and issues with respect to the State;
a description of the freight policies, strategies, and performance measures that will guide the freight-related transportation investment decisions of the State;

subparagraph.content: multimodal critical rural freight facilities and corridors designated within the State under section 70103 of this title; and
critical rural and urban freight corridors designated within the State under section 167 of title 23;

paragraph.content: a description of how the plan will improve the ability of the State to meet the national multimodal freight policy goals described in section 70101(b) of this title and the national highway freight program goals described in section 167 of title 23;

a description of how innovative technologies and operational strategies, including freight intelligent transportation systems, that improve the safety and efficiency of freight movement, were considered;

in the case of roadways on which travel by heavy vehicles (including mining, agricultural, energy cargo or equipment, and timber vehicles) is projected to substantially deteriorate the condition of the roadways, a description of improvements that may be required to reduce or impede the deterioration;

an inventory of facilities with freight mobility issues, such as bottlenecks, within the State, and for those facilities that are State owned or operated, a description of the strategies the State is employing to address the freight mobility issues;
consideration of any significant congestion or delay caused by freight movements and any strategies to mitigate that congestion or delay;

a freight investment plan that, subject to subsection (c)(2), includes a list of priority projects and describes how funds made available to carry out section 167 of title 23 would be invested and matched;
the most recent commercial motor vehicle parking facilities assessment conducted by the State under subsection (f);
the most recent supply chain cargo flows in the State, expressed by mode of transportation;
an inventory of commercial ports in the State;
if applicable, consideration of the findings or recommendations made by any multi-State freight compact to which the State is a party under section 70204;
the impacts of e-commerce on freight infrastructure in the State;
considerations of military freight;

subparagraph.content: the severity of impacts of extreme weather and natural disasters on freight mobility;
the impacts of freight movement on local air pollution;
the impacts of freight movement on flooding and stormwater runoff; and
the impacts of freight movement on wildlife habitat loss; and

paragraph.content: consultation with the State freight advisory committee, if applicable.

paragraph.heading: Incorporation.—
paragraph.content: A State freight plan described in subsection (a) may be developed separately from or incorporated into the statewide strategic long-range transportation plan required by section 135 of title 23.

paragraph.heading: Fiscal constraint.—
paragraph.content: The freight investment plan component of a freight plan shall include a project, or an identified phase of a project, only if funding for completion of the project can reasonably be anticipated to be available for the project within the time period identified in the freight investment plan.

subsection.heading: Planning Period.—
subsection.content: A State freight plan described in subsection (a) shall address a 8-year forecast period.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: A State shall update a State freight plan described in subsection (a) not less frequently than once every 4 years.

paragraph.heading: Freight investment plan.—
paragraph.content: A State may update a freight investment plan described in subsection (b)(9) more frequently than is required under paragraph (1).

subsection.heading: Commercial Motor Vehicle Parking Facilities Assessments.—
subsection.chapeau: As part of the development or updating, as applicable, of a State freight plan under this section, each State that receives funding under section 167 of title 23, in consultation with relevant State motor carrier safety personnel, shall conduct an assessment of—

paragraph.content: the capability of the State, together with the private sector in the State, to provide adequate parking facilities and rest facilities for commercial motor vehicles engaged in interstate transportation;
the volume of commercial motor vehicle traffic in the State; and

whether there exist any areas within the State with a shortage of adequate commercial motor vehicle parking facilities, including an analysis (economic or otherwise, as the State determines to be appropriate) of the underlying causes of such a shortage.

subsection.heading: Priority.—
subsection.chapeau: Each State freight plan under this section shall include a requirement that the State, in carrying out activities under the State freight plan—

paragraph.content: enhance reliability or redundancy of freight transportation; or
incorporate the ability to rapidly restore access and reliability with respect to freight transportation.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary of Transportation shall approve a State freight plan described in subsection (a) if the plan achieves compliance with the requirements of this section.

paragraph.heading: Savings provision.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this subsection establishes new procedural requirements for the approval of a State freight plan described in subsection (a).

section.heading: Transportation investment data and planning tools

subsection.heading: In General.—
subsection.chapeau: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this section, the Secretary of Transportation shall—

paragraph.chapeau: begin development of new tools and improvement of existing tools to support an outcome-oriented, performance-based approach to evaluate proposed freight-related and other transportation projects, including—

subparagraph.content: methodologies for systematic analysis of benefits and costs on a national or regional basis;

tools for ensuring that the evaluation of freight-related and other transportation projects could consider safety, economic competitiveness, urban and rural access, environmental sustainability, and system condition in the project selection process;
improved methods for data collection and trend analysis;
encouragement of public-private collaboration to carry out data sharing activities while maintaining the confidentiality of all proprietary data; and
other tools to assist in effective transportation planning;

paragraph.content: identify transportation-related model data elements to support a broad range of evaluation methods and techniques to assist in making transportation investment decisions; and

at a minimum, in consultation with other relevant Federal agencies, consider any improvements to existing freight flow data collection efforts that could reduce identified freight data gaps and deficiencies and help improve forecasts of freight transportation demand.

subsection.heading: Consultation.—
subsection.content: The Secretary shall consult with Federal, State, and other stakeholders to develop, improve, and implement the tools and collect the data described in subsection (a).

subsection.heading: Consent to Multi-State Freight Mobility Compacts.—
subsection.chapeau: Congress recognizes the right of States, cities, regional planning organizations, federally recognized Indian Tribes, and local public authorities (including public port authorities) that are regionally linked with an interest in a specific nationally or regionally significant multi-State freight corridor to enter into multi-State compacts to promote the improved mobility of goods, including—

paragraph.content: identifying projects along the corridor that benefit multiple States;
assembling rights-of-way; and
performing capital improvements.

subsection.heading: Financing.—
subsection.chapeau: A multi-State freight compact established by entities under subsection (a) may provide that, in order to carry out the compact, the relevant States or other entities may—

paragraph.content: accept contributions from a unit of State or local government;
use any Federal or State funds made available for freight mobility infrastructure planning or construction, including applying for grants;

paragraph.chapeau: subject to such terms and conditions as the States consider to be advisable—

subparagraph.content: borrow money on a short-term basis; and

clause.content: notes for borrowing under subparagraph (A); and
bonds; and

paragraph.content: obtain financing by other means permitted under applicable Federal or State law.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: A multi-State freight compact under this section may establish a multi-State freight corridor advisory committee, which shall include representatives of State departments of transportation and other public and private sector entities with an interest in freight mobility, such as—

subparagraph.content: ports;
freight railroads;
shippers;
carriers;
freight-related associations;
third-party logistics providers;
the freight industry workforce;
environmental organizations;
community organizations; and
units of local government.

paragraph.heading: Activities.—
paragraph.chapeau: An advisory committee established under paragraph (1) may—

subparagraph.chapeau: advise the parties to the applicable multi-State freight compact with respect to freight-related priorities, issues, projects, and funding needs that impact multi-State—

clause.content: freight mobility; and
supply chains;

subparagraph.content: serve as a forum for States, Indian Tribes, and other public entities to discuss decisions affecting freight mobility;
communicate and coordinate multi-State freight priorities with other organizations;
promote the sharing of information between the private and public sectors with respect to freight issues; and
provide information for consideration in the development of State freight plans under section 70202.

paragraph.heading: Establishment.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary of Transportation (referred to in this section as the “Secretary”) shall establish a program under which the Secretary shall provide grants to multi-State freight compacts, or States seeking to form a multi-State freight compact, that seek to improve a route or corridor that is a part of the National Multimodal Freight Network established under section 70103.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: To incentivize the establishment of multi-State freight compacts, the Secretary may award a grant for operations costs in an amount of not more than $2,000,000 to—

clause.content: a multi-State freight compact established under subsection (a) during the 2-year period beginning on the date of establishment of the multi-State freight compact; or
States seeking to form a multi-State freight compact described in that subsection.

clause.heading: New multi-state freight compacts.—
clause.content: A multi-State freight compact shall be eligible for a grant under this paragraph only during the initial 2 years of operation of the compact.

clause.heading: States seeking to form a compact.—
clause.chapeau: States seeking to form a multi-State freight compact shall be eligible for a grant under this paragraph during—

subclause.content: the 2-year period beginning on the date on which an application for a grant under this paragraph with respect to the proposed compact is submitted to the Secretary; or
if the compact is formed before the date on which a grant under this paragraph is awarded in accordance with subclause (I), the initial 2 years of operation of the compact.

subparagraph.heading: Requirements.—
subparagraph.chapeau: To be eligible to receive a grant under this paragraph, a multi-State freight compact or the applicable States seeking to form a multi-State freight compact shall—

clause.content: submit to the Secretary an application at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require;
provide a non-Federal match equal to not less than 25 percent of the operating costs of the multi-State freight compact; and
commit to establishing a multi-State freight corridor advisory committee under subsection (c)(1) during the initial 2-year period of operation of the compact.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The Secretary may award a grant to multi-State freight compacts that are not eligible to receive a grant under paragraph (2) for operations costs in an amount of not more than $1,000,000.

subparagraph.heading: Requirements.—
subparagraph.chapeau: To be eligible to receive a grant under this paragraph, a multi-State freight compact shall—

clause.content: submit to the Secretary an application at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require;
provide a non-Federal match of not less than 50 percent of the operating costs of the compact; and
demonstrate that the compact has established a multi-State freight corridor advisory committee under subsection (c)(1).

paragraph.heading: Authorization of appropriations.—
paragraph.content: There is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary $5,000,000 for each fiscal year to carry out this subsection.

section.heading: National multimodal cooperative freight research program

subsection.heading: Establishment.—
subsection.content: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this section, the Secretary of Transportation (referred to in this section as the “Secretary”) shall establish and support a national cooperative freight transportation research program.

heading.inline: Administration by National Academy of Sciences.—

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall enter into an agreement with the National Academy of Sciences to support and carry out administrative and management activities under the program established under subsection (a).

paragraph.heading: Advisory committee.—
paragraph.chapeau: To assist the National Academy of Sciences in carrying out this subsection, the National Academy shall establish an advisory committee, the members of which represent a cross-section of multimodal freight stakeholders, including—

subparagraph.content: the Department of Transportation and other relevant Federal departments and agencies;
State (including the District of Columbia) departments of transportation;
units of local government, including public port authorities;
nonprofit entities;
institutions of higher education;
labor organizations representing employees in freight industries; and
private sector entities representing various transportation modes.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The advisory committee established under subsection (b)(2), in consultation with interested parties, shall recommend a national research agenda for the program in accordance with subsection (d), which shall include a multiyear strategic plan.

subparagraph.heading: Action by interested parties.—
subparagraph.chapeau: For purposes of subparagraph (A), an interested party may—

clause.content: submit to the advisory committee research proposals;
participate in merit reviews of research proposals and peer reviews of research products; and
receive research results.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The National Academy of Sciences may award research contracts and grants under the program established under subsection (a) through—

clause.content: open competition; and
merit review, conducted on a regular basis.

clause.heading: Peer review.—
clause.content: A contract or grant for research under subparagraph (A) may allow peer review of the research results.

clause.heading: Programmatic evaluations.—
clause.content: The National Academy of Sciences may conduct periodic programmatic evaluations on a regular basis of a contract or grant for research under subparagraph (A).

subparagraph.heading: Dissemination of findings.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The National Academy of Sciences shall disseminate the findings of any research conducted under this paragraph to relevant researchers, practitioners, and decisionmakers through—

clause.content: conferences and seminars;
field demonstrations;
workshops;
training programs;
presentations;
testimony to government officials;
publicly accessible websites;
publications for the general public; and
other appropriate means.

paragraph.heading: Report.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 1 year after the date of establishment of the program under subsection (a), and annually thereafter, the Secretary shall make available on a public website a report that describes the ongoing research and findings under the program.

subsection.heading: Areas for Research.—
subsection.chapeau: The national research agenda under subsection (c)(1) shall consider research in the following areas:

paragraph.chapeau: Improving the efficiency and resiliency of freight movement, including—

subparagraph.content: improving the connections between rural areas and domestic and foreign markets;
maximizing infrastructure utility, including improving urban curb-use efficiency;
quantifying the national impact of blocked railroad crossings;
improved techniques for estimating and quantifying public benefits derived from freight transportation projects; and
low-cost methods to reduce congestion at bottlenecks.

paragraph.chapeau: Adapting to future trends in freight, including—

subparagraph.content: considering the impacts of e-commerce;
automation; and
zero-emissions transportation.
diversifying the freight transportation industry workforce; and
creating and transitioning a workforce capable of designing, deploying, and operating emerging technologies.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Federal share of the cost of an activity carried out under this section shall be up to 100 percent.

paragraph.heading: Use of non-federal funds.—
paragraph.content: In addition to using funds made available to carry out this section, the National Academy of Sciences may seek and accept additional funding from public and private entities capable of accepting funding from the Department of Transportation, States, units of local government, nonprofit entities, and the private sector.

subsection.heading: Authorization of Appropriations.—
subsection.content: There is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary $3,750,000 for each fiscal year to carry out the program established under subsection (a), to remain available until expended.

subsection.heading: Sunset.—
subsection.content: The program established under subsection (a) shall terminate 5 years after the date of enactment of this section.

content.p: Nothing in this subtitle provides additional authority to regulate or direct private activity on freight networks designated under this subtitle.
